IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 15449 S0926-860X(15)30054-5 10.1016/j.apcata.2015.07.002 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the dried (left) and calcined samples (right). PDF2 patterns: malachite 76-0660, Cu-hydrotalcite 37-0630, ZnO 36-1451, CuO 48-1458 and Co3O4 42-1467; ICDD database. Fig. 2 TG profiles of the dried catalyst precursors (Cu/Co=1.4 and 1.9). Gases evolved during thermal decomposition were detected online by QMS and indicated at the DTG curves. Fig. 3 TPR profiles of the Cu–Co-based catalysts using a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1 up to 350°C and a flow of 5% H2 in Ar. The temperature was kept constant at 350°C for 15h. Fig. 4 CO conversion during the first 10h time on stream for the catalysts with different Cu/Co ratios tested at 280°C, 60bar, H2/CO=1 and 9600mlh−1 gcat −1. Fig. 5 Initial total selectivities to oxygenates (squares) and hydrocarbons (circles) obtained at 280°C, 60bar, 9600mlh−1 gcat −1 and H2/CO=1 during the first 10h on stream. Fig. 6 Selectivities to linear alcohols and hydrocarbons for the catalyst with a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 at 280°C, 60bar, 9600mlh−1 gcat −1 and H2/CO=1, and the estimated chain growth probabilities for linear alcohols αalcohol and hydrocarbons. Fig. 7 XRD pattern of the reduced catalyst and the catalyst after reaction with a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5. PDF2 patterns: Cu 00-004-0836 and ZnO 01-078-3322; ICDD database. Fig. 8 Zn 2p, Cu 2p and Co 2p XP spectra after reduction and after HAS for the catalyst with a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5. Table 1 Actual metal composition in wt% and molar Cu/Co ratio of the calcined precursors determined by ICP-OES. Cu/Co ratio Co (wt%) Cu (wt%) Zn (wt%) Al (wt%) 1.1 26.6 32.4 17.3 3.0 1.4 21.8 32.4 18.0 3.0 1.9 17.1 34.8 19.3 3.3 2.5 13.6 36.2 16.8 3.6 Table 2 Textural and surface properties of the catalysts. Cu/Co ratio A s,BET (m2 g−1) r p (nm) V p (cm3 g−1) Degree of reduction c (%) RFC N2O-consumption (μmolg−1) 1.1 a 122 3–5 0.23 83 489 1.4 a 133 3–5 0.38 92 464 1.9 a 108 3–4 0.23 94 451 2.5 a 104 4–5 0.30 99 457 2.5 b 70 5–6 0.30 251 a N2 physisorption measured after calcination, N2O-RFC measured after TPR. b N2 physisorption and N2O-RFC measured after 40h time on stream at 280°C, 60bar and H2/CO=1. c Calculated from the H2 consumption during TPR assuming the reduction of CuO and Co3O4 in the precursor. Table 3 CO conversion, product distribution, and chain growth probabilities α for alcohols and hydrocarbons with varying Cu/Co ratios after 40h time on stream. Table 4 Surface composition and ratios derived from the XPS results after reduction and after HAS compared with the precipitated bulk ratios for the catalyst with a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5. Surface composition (at%) Cu Co Zn Al O C Reduced 14.1 3.5 9.7 23.0 30.6 19.1 After reaction 7.2 3.1 6.6 8.4 30.3 44.4 Metal ratios Cu/Co Zn/Cu Zn/Co Bulk 2.5 0.5 1.1 Reduced 4.0 0.7 2.8 After reaction 2.3 0.9 2.1 Structure–activity relationships of Co-modified Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts applied in the synthesis of higher alcohols from synthesis gas Johan Anton a Janine Nebel a Huiqing Song a Christian Froese a Philipp Weide a Holger Ruland a Martin Muhler a Stefan Kaluza a b ⁎ a Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry, Ruhr-University Bochum, 44780 Bochum, Germany Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry Ruhr-University Bochum Bochum 44780 Germany b Fraunhofer UMSICHT, 46047 Oberhausen, Germany Fraunhofer UMSICHT Oberhausen 46047 Germany ⁎ Corresponding author at: Fraunhofer UMSICHT, 46047 Oberhausen, Germany. Fax: +49 208 8598 1423. Graphical abstract Cu–Co-based catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation using Cu, Co, Zn and Al nitrates and applied in higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) at 280°C, 60bar and a ratio of H2/CO=1. The catalyst exhibiting a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 was found to provide the best trade-off between product distribution and degree of CO conversion. After activation and 40h time on stream reaching steady-state conditions the bulk and surface properties of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated without exposing it to air during the transfer and the measurements. The conditions during activation and HAS led to a significant enrichment of Zn in the surface composition of the catalysts. The XRD pattern of the catalyst after reaction compared with the reduced catalyst revealed further sintering of the metallic Cu nanoparticles and the growth of crystalline ZnO nanoparticles, but there were no indications for the presence of bulk metallic Co or for bulk alloying. With increasing time on stream the product distribution shifted favorably towards higher alcohols presumably due to an increased intimate interface contact between the large metallic Cu0 particles detected by XRD and the X-ray amorphous metallic Co surface species probed by XPS. Keywords Higher alcohol synthesis Co-precipitation Cu–Co-based catalysts Strong metal-support interactions 1 Introduction The conversion of biomass-derived synthesis gas to ethanol and higher alcohols is a promising route for providing alternative transportation fuels and important chemical feedstocks [1–3]. Especially Rh-based catalysts are highly selective towards higher alcohols due to the unique property of Rh to facilitate both the dissociative as well as the non-dissociative adsorption of CO [4–9]. A well-balanced interplay between both steps is considered essential for higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) [10]. Catalysts based on non-noble metals such as modified Fischer–Tropsch (FT) and modified methanol synthesis catalysts were developed aiming at large-scale industrial applications [11–15]. As Cu adsorbs CO molecularly, while the adsorption on Co or Fe occurs dissociatively, the combination of both chemical functions in one catalyst may provide an economical alternative to noble metal-based systems. Both active sites have to be present in an optimal ratio and in close structural vicinity to meet the mechanistic requirements requiring well-controlled catalyst preparation. As the catalyst preparation must be highly scalable for industrial applications, co-precipitation from aqueous solutions is strongly favored. The formation of the catalyst precursor during the precipitation strongly depends on process parameters such as the metal salt concentrations, the applied precipitant, the mixing conditions, the control of the pH, the precipitation temperature and the aging conditions [16]. Depending on the selected conditions, various precursor phases with different chemical compositions and structural properties are formed. An accurate and reproducible preparation method is mandatory, but the conditions during activation by reduction and reaction are often equally decisive for the final properties of the catalyst. A large number of publications can be found in literature dealing with structure–activity relationships of Cu-based catalysts for HAS [17], but there is hardly any information available about the reduced state and the catalyst after reaction, which is the basis for establishing reliable structure–activity relationships. Especially Cu-based catalysts are highly sensitive to high temperatures during reduction and in the presence of syngas requiring well-chosen parameters in order to minimize the extent of sintering. In situ catalyst characterization under high temperature and high pressure conditions is rather demanding. Due to the pyrophoric nature of the reduced catalyst, the contact with air after reaction has to be avoided with great care to obtain reliable characterization results. In the present work different Co-modified Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation in order to derive an optimal Cu/Co ratio for HAS. The catalyst with the most promising ratio was characterized thoroughly after activation by H2 reduction and after HAS at 280°C (40h TOS) under inert conditions by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), N2O reactive frontal chromatography (N2O-RFC) and N2 physisorption. 2 Experimental Catalysts with different Cu/Co ratios were prepared by co-precipitation similar to those reported by the Institut Français du Pétrole (IFP) [11]. A metal salt solution (1M) of cobalt, copper, zinc and aluminium nitrates with the desired Cu:Zn:Al ratio was pumped into a vessel containing preheated (65°C) deionized water while continuously stirring. The precipitation was carried out at a constant pH of 7 by simultaneous addition of Na2CO3 solution (1.2M) by using an autotitrator while keeping the precipitation temperature at 65°C. Subsequent aging after precipitation of the suspension took place for 2h at 65°C. The precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water while stirring until it was Na-free and finally dried for 20h at 120°C. The dried precursor was mortared and calcined in synthetic air at 350°C for 3h with a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. The metal composition as well as the absence of residual Na was determined by atomic emission spectroscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES) using an UNICAM PU 7000. The specific surface area (BET method) and pore structure were determined by static nitrogen physisorption (Quantachrome Autosorb-1-MP) after degassing at 200°C. The pore size distribution and the pore volume were obtained using the BJH method. Phase analysis by powder XRD was performed in reflection geometry with an Empyrean Theta–Theta diffractometer (Panalytical, Almelo) equipped with a Cu anode, 0.5° antiscatter slit for the incident beam, 7.5mm high antiscatter slit for the diffracted beam, 0.25° divergent slit, 0.04rad soller slit and a PIXcel-1d detector. A Ni filter was used to suppress the K-beta emission line. The XRD patterns were recorded over a 2θ range of 5–80° with a 0.0131 step width and 250s collection time. The XRD patterns of the reduced and spent samples were obtained with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation, 0.4mm antiscatter slit (incident beam), 0.4mm antiscatter slit (diffracted beam), 1.5 rad soller slit and a silicon-strip detector called Lynx Eye. The samples were mounted in standard capillaries with a diameter of 0.7mm under inert gas atmosphere, and the XRD patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5–45° with a 0.0103 step width and 0.5s/step collection time. Powder diffraction files (PDF) from the International Center of Diffraction Data (ICDD) and X’Pert HighScore Plus software (PANalytical) were used for qualitative phase analysis. Thermal analysis was performed on a Cahn TG 2013 instrument using 100mlmin−1 of 20% O2 in He. About 30mg of the sample were heated up to 800°C applying a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. Gases evolved during thermal decomposition were detected online by QMS. XPS was performed in ultra-high vacuum using a Gammadata-Scienta SES 2002 analyzer. Samples were prepared inside the glove box and transferred to the spectrometer under inert conditions excluding exposure to air. The spectra were obtained at 200eV pass energy (high pass energy mode) at a base pressure of 6×10−10 mbar with monochromatic Al Κα (1486.6eV, 14.5kV, 45mA) radiation resulting in a overall resolution of 0.6eV. A flood gun was used to compensate charging effects. As a charge reference the C 1s binding energy from adventitious hydrocarbon was used and fixed at 284.8eV. The spectrum deconvolution was achieved using the CasaXPS software with Shirley-type background subtraction and with sums of asymmetric Gaussian–Lorentzian functions. The surface composition and atomic ratios were estimated using the peak areas after background subtraction and the element-specific cross-sections. Since, the catalyst activation was carried out at 350°C for 15h in diluted H2 atmosphere, TPR was performed applying the same conditions in order to monitor the formation of the reduced state of the catalyst prior to HAS. The TPR experiments were carried out with 100mg of the calcined sample of the 250–355μm sieve fraction in a quartz reactor using a flow of Ar with 5vol% of H2. The temperature was increased from room temperature to 350°C with a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1 and was kept constant for 15h. Quantitative H2 consumption was derived using a calibrated thermal conductivity detector. N2O-RFC was performed after TPR at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. After reduction the sample was cooled in He (99.999%) prior to switching to 1% N2O in He (99.999%). A N2O sensitive IR photometer (URAS, ABB) was used for continuous online gas analysis. A detailed description can be found in literature [18]. The test facility comprised N2 (99.9999%) as internal standard and purge gas, H2 (99.9999%) for the reduction of the catalysts and premixed synthesis gas with CO (99.997%), H2 (99.9999%) and N2 (99.9999%) leading to an overall feed gas composition of CO:H2:N2 =40:40:20 (H2/CO=1). The reduction of the calcined catalyst was performed in the reactor with a heating rate of 5°C min−1 at 350°C for 15h in diluted H2 (H2/N2 =0.25). Activity measurements were performed with 250mg catalysts (particle sizes of 250–355μm) in a high pressure stainless-steel fixed-bed U-tube reactor at 280°C, 60bar and a volumetric feed rate of 40mlmin−1 synthesis gas resulting in a GHSV of 9600mlh−1 gcat −1. The U-tube reactor was positioned in a circulating air oven ensuring isothermal reaction conditions. Online gas chromatography was used for the quantitative analysis [19]. The most promising catalysts were flushed with inert gas, sealed by stainless-steel valves, and transferred into a glove box avoiding re-oxidation and contamination by air and were further prepared under Ar atmosphere for characterization. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst precursor The actual metal compositions of the calcined precursors determined by ICP-OES are summarized in Table 1 . A molar Cu:Zn:Al ratio of 60:27:13 was kept constant for all samples. Thorough and intensive washing of the precursors led to completely Na-free samples. This is of major importance as alkali compounds – even as trace impurities – are known to significantly influence the catalyst properties in HAS, making a reliable and comparable interpretation of the results difficult [11,19,20]. Despite different compositions all calcined catalyst precursors have rather similar specific surface areas (Table 2 ), which slightly increased with increasing Co content. In similar samples containing Co, Cu and Al without Zn, de Aguino and Gomez Cobo [21] observed a corresponding trend. Both the average pore diameter and the pore volume were only slightly affected by the catalyst composition (Table 2). The XRD patterns of the dried precursors are shown in Fig. 1 , left. Although a quite X-ray amorphous material was obtained after precipitation, several characteristic reflections were observed that can be assigned to different metal hydroxy carbonate phases well-known for Cu-based methanol synthesis catalysts [22,23]. Due to the similar ionic radii of the Co, Cu, and Zn cations together with the broad reflections of the poorly crystalline material it was difficult to determine the exact phase composition, but the formation of isomorphic phases such as M2(OH)2CO3 (malachite-type) and M5(OH)6(CO3)2 (aurichalcite-type) is rather likely. Additionally, an Al-containing phase of the hydrotalcite-type M6Al2(OH)16CO3 was assigned by its characteristic reflections at 2θ =11° (003), 24° (006) and 35° (009) [24,25], which became more prominent with increasing Cu/Co ratio. The X-ray amorphous character of the samples was retained even after calcination (Fig. 1, right). Few broad reflections were observed that can be assigned to CuO and ZnO, and the presence of mixed metal oxides cannot be excluded. The low intensities and the amorphous character of the oxide precursors suggest a high degree of dispersion and small particle sizes after calcination. Furthermore, the background was found to increase with increasing Cu/Co ratio indicating the presence of an additional amorphous phase. This observation is accompanied by the increased amount of hydrotalcite-type precursor phases formed with increasing Cu/Co ratio. Fig. 2 exemplarily shows the TG profiles of two dried catalyst precursors. For both samples the entire mass loss up to 800°C was found to be approximately 33%. Upon heating, H2O and CO2 were released due to the thermal decomposition of malachite- and hydrotalcite-type phases below 350°C. Above 400°C further decomposition was observed accompanied by the release of CO2, which is assigned to a high temperature carbonate species. With decreasing Cu content the high temperature carbonate decomposition is shifted to higher temperatures indicating an increased thermal stability. However, due to the chosen calcination temperature of 350°C the thermal decomposition of the hydrotalcite-type precursor phases was incomplete resulting in the formation of high temperature carbonate species, which were stable up to 450°C. Thus, an increasing amount of amorphous carbonate phase remained in the calcined precursor with increasing Cu content. Similar results were reported in literature for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts obtained from precursors containing hydrotalcite-type phases [26]. All TPR profiles shown in Fig. 3 consist of a sharp peak originating from the reduction of Cu2+ species with a maximum reduction temperature between 174°C and 194°C. With increasing Cu/Co ratio this peak was found to shift to lower temperatures. For Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts a shift to lower temperatures was observed for increasing amounts of hydrotalcite-type phases formed during catalyst preparation in agreement with our XRD results [26]. Two additional reduction steps give rise to shoulders in the TPR profiles of the samples with the highest and lowest Cu/Co ratio located to the right or to the left of the peak maximum, respectively. The H2 consumption at lower temperatures is assumed to be due to the reduction of high temperature-stable carbonate species resulting from the incomplete decomposition of hydrotalcite-type phases during calcination, whereas CuO formed from the thermal decomposition of the malachite and aurichalcite-type phases is reduced at higher temperatures. In addition, the reduction to metallic Cu is strongly influenced by the presence of Al, Zn and Co, and the presence of mixed metal oxides cannot be excluded. For the samples with a Cu/Co ratio of 1.4 and 1.9 only one broad peak was observed due to the superposition of the various Cu2+ reduction steps. The flat and broad reduction peak between 200°C and 350°C might suggest the reduction of more stable Cu2+ species, but in this temperature region usually the reduction of Co3+ species occurs [27,28]. The reduction of bivalent Co species to metallic Co usually requires temperatures higher than 350°C. The degree of reduction was derived from the respective H2 consumption profiles assuming the presence of CuO and Co3O4 in the calcined precursor. With increasing Cu/Co ratio the degree of reduction was found to increase (Table 2). Assuming the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO to occur at temperatures around 350°C, adsorbed atomic hydrogen could migrate from the Cu to the CoO nanoparticles thus favoring the reduction of Co2+ ions to Co0. Such a spillover mechanism between a metal and an oxide is favorable when either both species are present in one phase after precipitation or when well dispersed oxides or mixed metal oxides are received after calcination [29,30]. Thus, the high degree of reduction provides quantitative evidence for the close contact between Cu and Co species in the calcined precursor. For Cu-based catalysts the Cu surface area can be estimated by N2O-RFC, which is known to be a reproducible technique especially used for methanol synthesis catalysts: Two Cu surface atoms react with N2O to form Cusurf–O–Cusurf resulting in a Cusurf/N2O ratio of 2 [31,32]. For the reaction of N2O with Cosurf the resulting ratio is not known. Within the series of Cu–Co-based catalysts the N2O consumption was hardly influenced by the varying Cu/Co ratio (Table 2). Compared to the value of 217μmolg−1 for a typical Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalyst, the N2O consumption is noticeably increased, which may be due to additional bulk oxidation of metallic Co [18]. However, within the same series of Cu–Co samples N2O-RFC can provide an estimation of the amount of reduced metal surface sites. 3.2 Catalytic properties The relatively high initial temperature of 280°C caused a strong deactivation of the Cu–Co-based catalyst within the first 10h on stream (Fig. 4 ). Deactivation is typically known for Co-modified Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts operated at higher temperatures and is assumed to occur by phase transformations under reductive syngas atmosphere and sintering [33,34]. The initial high degree of CO conversion resulted from the formation of hydrocarbons due to the presence of metallic Co. With increasing Cu/Co ratio the overall initial activity was found to decrease (Fig. 4). While the product distribution during deactivation was rather constant for the catalysts with low Cu/Co ratio, the catalyst performance changed significantly especially for the Cu-rich catalysts. With increasing time on stream (TOS) the overall selectivity to alcohols increased, whereas the selectivity to long-chain hydrocarbons decreased (Fig. 5 ). Thus, deactivation was observed for all catalysts, but for the Cu-rich catalysts the changes in the active surface area were more beneficial for HAS. The results obtained under steady-state conditions after 40h TOS are summarized in Table 3 . With decreasing Cu/Co ratio the degree of CO conversion was found to increase. The higher activity is assigned to the high overall selectivity to long-chain hydrocarbons and CH4. Regardless of the Cu/Co ratio, within the hydrocarbons as well as alcohols the selectivity decreases with increasing chain length indicating a chain growth mechanism according to the Anderson–Schulz–Flory (ASF) distribution for both hydrocarbon and alcohol formation (Fig. 6 ). The chain growth probabilities α alcohol and α HC for linear alcohols and hydrocarbons, respectively, obtained after 40h TOS are summarized in Table 3. While the values for hydrocarbons were almost independent of the catalyst composition (0.50–0.56), the chain growth probability for alcohols was significantly lower and gradually decreased from 0.54 to 0.43 with increasing Cu/Co ratio. The overall selectivities to methanol, ethanol, and higher alcohols are increasing with increasing Cu/Co ratio. Additionally, the water-gas shift reaction is found to be favored since water is formed as coupled product of CO hydrogenation leading to increased CO2 formation. A further increase of the Cu/Co ratio beyond 2.5 resulted in lower degrees of CO conversion and increased formation of methanol as the major product (not shown). Within this series alcohols and other oxygenates summed up to selectivities of about 23–29%. The catalyst exhibiting a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 provides the best trade-off between product distribution and degree of CO conversion for further modification with alkali promoters. 3.3 Characterization of the reduced and spent catalysts Regardless of the Cu/Co ratio all catalysts undergo strong deactivation. To evaluate the catalyst state after activation and after HAS the sample with the Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 was characterized in detail after reduction and 40h TOS using inert conditions during transfer and storage to prevent re-oxidation and contamination by air. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalyst and the catalyst after reaction are shown in Fig. 7 . The presence of metallic Cu was confirmed after reduction, while reflections assigned to metallic Co were not found. The cubic metallic Cu phase was further investigated with standard X-ray powder diffraction techniques (internal line standard NIST SRM 640) to determine the lattice parameter a. Its value a =3.6160Å (± 0.0022, 2 sigma), refined from three diffraction lines, was indistinguishable from the lattice parameter of pure copper (a =3.615Å, PDF2 pattern 00-004-0836; ICDD database) and clearly differed from that of cubic Co, a =3.5447Å (PDF2 pattern 00-015-0806, ICDD database). Therefore, the XRD data indicate that bulk alloying of the metallic Cu phase with Co was negligible during reduction. However, the precise control of the reduction conditions and the catalyst preparation can indeed lead to CuCo alloy formation as reported in recent literature [35]. Obviously, sintering of the Cu nanoparticles proceeded during reduction since the Cu0 reflections are relatively intense (d Cu,red =11nm). Other reflections were hardly detectable but an additional amorphous phase can be assigned to ZnO. While ZnO almost appears X-ray amorphous after reduction a significant increase in the crystallinity with sharp and intense ZnO reflections was observed after 40h TOS. Additionally, while reflections assigned to Cu0 were already dominating in the pattern of the reduced sample, a slight further increase of the metallic Cu particle size was observed for the catalyst after reaction (d Cu,spent =15nm). The strong increase in crystallinity of ZnO during reaction is assumed to be caused by the presence of water vapor, which is the coupled product of the formation of higher alcohols and hydrocarbons. Bulk Co phases were not detected by XRD neither in the reduced nor in the spent catalyst indicating well-dispersed and small CoO x (0≤ x ≤1) particles. The high initial degree of CO conversion is mainly due to the strongly exothermic formation of short-chain hydrocarbons, which may lead to a further temperature increase within the catalyst bed. The decrease in specific surface area correlates with the slightly increased particle sizes after reaction (Table 2). Compared with the reduced state, the N2O consumption is lower suggesting changes in the surface composition due to sintering. Similar results were found by Xiaoding et al. [36] for Cu–Co-based catalysts after several months on stream. The chemical surface compositions of the reduced and spent catalyst were determined by XPS. The Co 2p3/2 and the Co 2p1/2 peaks were centered at 778eV and 793eV. Due to the poorer S/N-ratio of the Co 2p1/2 peak only the Co 2p3/2 peak was further analyzed (Fig. 8 ). The intense peak at 778.3eV and the weak satellite peaks at 781.0eV and 783.3eV indicate metallic Co0. The broadened peak at 780.4eV and the associated satellites at 782.5eV and 785.8eV indicate the presence of CoO. The Cu 2p3/2 peak is located at 932.8eV, and the Zn 2p3/2 peak is at 1022.4eV. In case of Cu and Zn the oxidation states of Cu0 and Zn2+ were determined by using the Wagner plot considering the corresponding binding energies of the 2p photoelectrons and the kinetic energies of the LMM Auger electrons. Co partially remains in the oxidized state at the surface even during HAS under strongly reducing conditions. The signal ratio between metallic Co and ionic Co2+ is increased after reaction indicating further reduction of Co2+ during HAS. The metal surface ratios between Co, Cu and Zn after reduction and after 40h TOS are summarized in Table 4 and are compared with the initial bulk composition. After reduction, the ZnO surface concentration was significantly increased compared with the initial concentration as indicated by higher Zn/Cu and Zn/Co ratios. For Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts the migration of ZnO x species and decoration of the Cu metal particles under reductive conditions is a well-known phenomenon termed strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [37,38]. Similar interactions between Cu and ZnO are suggested for the Zn-containing Cu–Co-based catalysts. However, compared with the Zn/Cu ratio the Zn/Co ratio is much more influenced resulting in a strong increase of the Cu/Co surface concentration ratio for the reduced catalysts. After 40h TOS the overall surface concentrations are found to be changed again: the Zn/Cu ratio was further increased accompanied by a strong decrease of the Cu/Co ratio while the decrease in the Zn/Co ratio was relatively small. The Cu/Co ratio after reaction is in good agreement with the bulk Cu/Co ratio. The increased surface carbon content after reaction points to the formation of strongly adsorbing molecules during HAS. 4 Discussion The XRD patterns of the reduced catalyst and the catalyst after reaction disclosed the absence of bulk metallic Co0. Moreover, bulk alloying of the metallic Cu phase with Co0 was negligible. Thus, well-dispersed X-ray amorphous CoO x (0≤ x ≤1) particles were formed during the reduction, because the XPS results obtained with the reduced catalyst (Fig. 8) revealed both the presence of metallic Co0 and ionic Co2+ at the surface. Interestingly, Co partially remained in the oxidized state even during HAS under strongly reducing conditions assuming ionic Co2+ to be stabilized by Al2O3 or ZnO. The formation of the CoAl2O4 spinel phase during calcination or the embedding of Co2+ ions in ZnO are expected to strongly affect the reducibility. The presence of exposed metallic Co0 nanoparticles is inferred from both the initial high degree of CO conversion (Fig. 4) and the high initial hydrocarbon selectivities (Fig. 5). Deactivation occurred for all catalysts and was accompanied by a shift in the product distribution towards higher alcohols. With proceeding deactivation, the changes in the active surfaces were beneficial for HAS pointing to an improved interface contact between Cu0 and Co0 nanoparticles. Such an intimate contact can result from both Cu–Co surface alloy formation as recently reported in literature [35] or the decoration of Cu0 nanoparticles by metallic Co0 islands leading to a modified and lower Cu/Co surface ratio as observed for the Cu–Co-based catalysts. The structural vicinity of Cu and Co nanoparticles is additionally suggested by the presence of metallic Co0 in the reduced catalyst, because the reduction of Co2+ usually requires temperatures higher than 350°C (Fig. 8): Metallic Cu0 is well known to increase the reducibility and activity of both Co- and Fe-based Fischer–Tropsch catalysts [39,40], and such a hydrogen spillover mechanism to promote Co2+ reduction requires an intimate interaction between metallic Cu0 and the CoO x species. Therefore, co-precipitation from aqueous solutions provides a suitable preparation method enabling the formation of a common precursor phase during precipitation in order to achieve a close contact of metallic Cu0 and Co0 sites after reduction. The XPS analysis of the reduced catalyst and the catalyst after reaction revealed an increased Zn/Cu and Zn/Co surface concentration ratios (Table 4) indicating the migration of ZnO x species decorating the Cu and Co metal nanoparticles under reducing conditions according to the SMSI model known for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts [41]. In case of typical SMSI of Cu and ZnO the synergetic interplay promotes the formation of methanol from CO2. For the Zn-containing Cu–Co-based catalysts the methanol synthesis activity was rather low compared with the hydrocarbon formation suggesting the presence of a different ZnO-modified Cu metal environment compared with the porous framework typically resulting from SMSI of Cu0 nanoparticles and ZnO x species. Behrens et al. [42] reported on partially embedded Cu0 nanoparticles in a disordered oxide matrix yielding an intimate interface contact between metal and oxide as a result of an altered catalyst preparation compared with the conventional synthesis of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalyst. Such an interaction both for Cu and Co nanoparticles embedded together in an oxide matrix should enable an intimate contact resulting in the desired catalytic properties for HAS. HRTEM studies are in progress to elucidate the structural details of the Cu–Co interaction. Based on the degree of CO conversion and the product distribution three types of active sites seem to be present in the Co-modified Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts. Obviously, exposed metallic Co0 sites lead to exclusively hydrocarbon formation, whereas a strong interaction between Cu0 nanoparticles and ZnO x species should promote methanol synthesis, because neither Fischer–Tropsch synthesis nor methanol synthesis from CO2 occur over plain metallic Cu0 sites. HAS should require the close contact of Cu0 and Co0 sites, as a well-balanced interplay of both dissociative as well as non-dissociative adsorption of CO is considered essential. The presence of different active sites is further confirmed by the estimated chain growth probabilities. The α-values for linear alcohols and hydrocarbons differ significantly. Moreover, while the chain growth probability for hydrocarbons is almost independent of the catalyst composition, it is gradually decreasing for alcohols with increasing Cu/Co ratio. This result indicates that the formation of hydrocarbons occurs on other sites, most likely Co0 sites, than the formation of alcohols. With time on stream the deactivation of the Cu–Co-based catalysts was accompanied by a shift in the product distribution in favor of higher alcohols at the expense of hydrocarbon formation. The decreasing hydrocarbon selectivity with time on stream is assumed to be caused by gradual coking of the exposed metallic Co0 already present after reduction. Simultaneously, residual CoO x is further reduced providing increased intimate contact between the large metallic Cu0 particles and metallic Co surface species resulting in surface alloying, which should lead to increased selectivities to higher alcohols. According to this hypothesis, both the reduction and the reaction conditions have to be optimized carefully to obtain high yields of higher alcohols. The catalyst exhibiting a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 providing the best trade-off between product distribution and degree of CO conversion is currently used for further chain growth modification with alkali compounds, which are known to promote the chain growth probability . 5 Conclusions A series of Cu–Co-based catalysts was prepared by co-precipitation, reduced at 350°C, and tested in higher alcohol synthesis at 280°C, 60bar and a ratio of H2/CO=1. Regardless of the Cu/Co ratio all catalysts strongly deactivated under HAS reaction conditions. The formation of higher alcohols was found to be favored by an increasing Cu/Co ratio, and a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 was identified as optimum composition in terms of activity and selectivity. Within the alcohols formed the selectivity decreased with increasing chain length indicating a chain growth mechanism according to the Anderson–Schulz–Flory distribution. The presence of metallic Co sites after activation was confirmed by the catalytic properties and by XPS, whereas the XRD pattern was dominated by large metallic Cu reflections. According to the Scherrer equation Cu0 nanoparticles with mean diameters of 11nm and 15nm were found after reduction and after 40h TOS under reaction conditions, respectively. The reduction of ionic Co species was found to be favored even at 350°C presumably due to hydrogen spillover from metallic Cu. The surface composition was strongly affected by the conditions during activation and HAS. The migration of ZnO x species decorating both Cu and Co metal nanoparticles was found to occur under reducing conditions. With increasing time on stream, the product distribution was shifted towards higher alcohols during deactivation. This phenomenon is ascribed to gradual coking of exposed Co0 sites leading to decreased hydrocarbon formation accompanied by an improved intimate interface contact between the large metallic Cu0 nanoparticles detected by XRD and the X-ray amorphous metallic Co surface species probed by XPS favoring the synthesis of higher alcohols. Acknowledgement The work was part of the project “Bioethanol from synthesis gas—BETSY”, funded by the Ministry for Economy, Energy, Building, Habitation and Transportation of Northrhine-Westphalia within the program Ziel2.NRW financed by the European Union through the European regional development fund ERDF. coredata.dc:description: Cu–Co-based catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation using Cu, Co, Zn and Al nitrates and applied in higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) at 280°C, 60bar and a ratio of H2/CO=1. The catalyst exhibiting a Cu/Co ratio of 2.5 was found to provide the best trade-off between product distribution and degree of CO conversion. After activation and 40h time on stream reaching steady-state conditions the bulk and surface properties of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated without exposing it to air during the transfer and the measurements. The conditions during activation and HAS led to a significant enrichment of Zn in the surface composition of the catalysts. The XRD pattern of the catalyst after reaction compared with the reduced catalyst revealed further sintering of the metallic Cu nanoparticles and the growth of crystalline ZnO nanoparticles, but there were no indications for the presence of bulk metallic Co or for bulk alloying. With increasing time on stream the product distribution shifted favorably towards higher alcohols presumably due to an increased intimate interface contact between the large metallic Cu0 particles detected by XRD and the X-ray amorphous metallic Co surface species probed by XPS.
coredata.dc:title: Structure–activity relationships of Co-modified Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts applied in the synthesis of higher alcohols from synthesis gas
